Award.AwardTitle: CSBR: Natural History: Curation and Digitization of Newly Acquired Modern and Fossil Invertebrate and Protist Research Collections at the SDSM&T Museum of Geology
Award.AbstractNarration:
An award was made to the South Dakota School of Mines and Technology Museum of Geology to curate and digitize three recently acquired collections of modern and Neogene-age (last 23 million years) invertebrates and protists. The targeted collections represent ancient and recent shallow-marine environments and are a foundation for conservation paleobiology and contemporary ecological research. Materials include 1989-2011 field collections of PI Anderson, dissertation collections of co-PI Belanger, and an orphaned collection from the former University of South Dakota-Springfield. Products of this project will include well-curated collections; digitized and georeferenced records including ancillary data, and illustrated faunal lists.

Outreach and educational activities of this project include the training of graduate and undergraduate students in modern curatorial techniques. College students will also be involved in designing exhibits for use in outreach to middle and high school students. Furthermore, the targeted specimens will be used in course development for the training of the next generation of museum curators, including students from state and tribal colleges. Participating students will be encouraged to become intellectually invested through the development of research projects using the collections. More information can be found at: http://www.sdsmt.edu/MuseumCollections.

Institution.Name: South Dakota School of Mines and Technology
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: SOUTH DAKOTA SCHOOL OF MINES & TECHNOLOGY

Performance_Institution.Name: South Dakota School of Mines and Technology

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
The major goals of this project were curate modern and Neogene-aged (last 23 million years) collections accessioned between 2011 and 2012 into the Museum of Geology (MOG) at the South Dakota School of Mines and Technology (SDSM) and to make the data publicly available online. These collections are invaluable archives of past biodiversity for research and educational efforts related to conservation paleobiology and historical ecology. These data are now accessible to the public and scientific community for new research and education endeavor through iDigBio (https://www.idigbio.org/portal/recordsets/db3181c9-48dd-489f-96ab-a5888f5a938c) and the Global Biodiversity Information Facility (https://www.gbif.org/publisher/f3b58cd2-a559-4f3a-b94d-01448b508821).

A total of 889,796 specimens were digitized as part of this project. Collections include Neogene-aged shallow-marine assemblages from the New World tropics and subtropics from the last 23 million years (Ma); subfossil and modern death assemblages from the Gulf of Mexico; samples of live-collected snails, mussels, and oysters from the US Gulf Coast collected before and after the 2010 BP oil spill; samples spanning ~20-16 Ma from Oregon; and a historic collection of modern clams, snails, and corals from the US coasts, Caribbean, and Indo-West Pacific.

Mentoring, educational, and outreach activities were integral to the project and included training in museum curation, collections digitization, virtual and ‘real’ exhibit design, and outreach to the public. Eight graduate students and 13 undergraduates received training as part of this grant. These collections were used in college classes in paleontology at Texas A&M University and SDSM, in museum curation courses at SDSM, and in a museum exhibit design course at SDSM. Collections also have been used in one MS thesis and three senior theses at SDSM.

Public outreach includes entries into the Museum collections web blog “Transforming Time into Space” (https://mogcollections.wordpress.com), typically with student contributors; online (http://www.sdsmt.edu/Academics/Museum-of-Geology/Online-Exhibits/) and physical exhibits constructed by students in the MOG; and collaboration with the Digital Atlas of Ancient Life. Data from the project collections also have been used in professional presentations and scholarly publications.

 


Last Modified: 08/27/2019
Modified by: Laurie C Anderson
